The route uses the [...slug] syntax to capture all path segments and joins them in the response. This works for paths like /api/post/a, /api/post/a/b, and /api/post/a/b/c.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nimport type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'\\n\\nexport default function handler(req: NextApiRequest, res: NextApiResponse) {\\n  const { slug } = req.query\\n  res.end(&#96;Post: ${slug.join(', ')}&#96;)\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;javascript\\nexport default function handler(req, res) {\\n  const { slug } = req.query\\n  res.end(&#96;Post: ${slug.join(', ')}&#96;)\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### Access Dynamic Route Parameters in Image Generation\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/01-metadata/opengraph-image.mdx\\n\\nDemonstrates how to access dynamic route parameters in opengraph-image or twitter-image route handlers. The params parameter is a Promise that resolves to an object containing route segment values, allowing you to generate images based on the current URL path and dynamic segments.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nexport default async function Image({\\n  params,\\n}: {\\n  params: Promise&lt;{ slug: string }&gt;\\n}) {\\n  const { slug } = await params\\n  // ...\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;javascript\\nexport default async function Image({ params }) {\\n  const { slug } = await params\\n  // ...\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### Create dynamic API Route with path parameters in Next.js\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/02-pages/03-building-your-application/01-routing/07-api-routes.mdx\\n\\nDemonstrates creating dynamic API routes using bracket notation in filenames (e.g., [pid].ts). Accesses query parameters from the request and returns a response containing the parameter value.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nimport type { NextApiRequest, NextApiResponse } from 'next'\\n\\nexport default function handler(req: NextApiRequest, res: NextApiResponse) {\\n  const { pid } = req.query\\n  res.end(&#96;Post: ${pid}&#96;)\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;javascript\\nexport default function handler(req, res) {\\n  const { pid } = req.query\\n  res.end(&#96;Post: ${pid}&#96;)\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### GET /items\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers.mdx\\n\\nDemonstrates an example of a GET Route Handler that fetches data from an external API and is configured for static caching.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;APIDOC\\n## GET /items (Route Handler Example)\\n\\n### Description\\nThis example demonstrates a GET Route Handler designed to fetch data from an external API and return it as a JSON response. It is configured for static caching to optimize performance.\\n\\n### Method\\nGET\\n\\n### Endpoint\\n&#96;/items&#96; (Implemented at &#96;app/items/route.ts&#96;)\\n\\n### Parameters\\n#### Path Parameters\\n// No path parameters for this example.\\n\\n#### Query Parameters\\n// No query parameters for this example.\\n\\n#### Request Body\\n// GET requests typically do not have a request body.\\n\\n### Request Example\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;json\\n{}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n### Response\\n#### Success Response (200)\\n- **data** (object) - An object containing the fetched data. The exact structure depends on the external API's response.\\n\\n#### Response Example\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;json\\n{\\n  \\\"data\\\": {\\n    \\\"id\\\": \\\"item123\\\",\\n    \\\"name\\\": \\\"Example Item\\\",\\n    \\\"value\\\": 100\\n  }\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n### Code Example\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nexport const dynamic = 'force-static'\\n\\nexport async function GET() {\\n  const res = await fetch('https://data.mongodb-api.com/...', {\\n    headers: {\\n      'Content-Type': 'application/json',\\n      'API-Key': process.env.DATA_API_KEY,\\n    },\\n  })\\n  const data = await res.json()\\n\\n  return Response.json({ data })\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### Handle Dynamic Route Segments in Next.js Route Handler\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/03-file-conventions/route.mdx\\n\\nCreate request handlers that respond to dynamic URL segments using [slug] syntax. The params object is a Promise containing route parameters extracted from the URL path. Supports multiple route variations matching different dynamic segments.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nexport async function GET(\\n  request: Request,\\n  { params }: { params: Promise&lt;{ slug: string }&gt; }\\n) {\\n  const { slug } = await params // 'a', 'b', or 'c'\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;javascript\\nexport async function GET(request, { params }) {\\n  const { slug } = await params // 'a', 'b', or 'c'\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### Typed GET Route Handler with RouteContext\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/01-getting-started/15-route-handlers.mdx\\n\\nA TypeScript GET Route Handler using the RouteContext helper to type the context parameter and access route parameters. This demonstrates how to properly type dynamic route segments like [id].\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nimport type { NextRequest } from 'next/server'\\n\\nexport async function GET(_req: NextRequest, ctx: RouteContext&lt;'/users/[id]'&gt;) {\\n  const { id } = await ctx.params\\n  return Response.json({ id })\\n}\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n### router.refresh() - Refresh Current Route\\n\\nSource: https://github.com/vercel/next.js/blob/canary/docs/01-app/03-api-reference/04-functions/use-router.mdx\\n\\nRefresh the current route by making a new request to the server, re-fetching data, and re-rendering Server Components while preserving client-side state.\\n\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;APIDOC\\n## router.refresh()\\n\\n### Description\\nRefresh the current route by making a new request to the server, re-fetching data requests, and re-rendering Server Components. The client merges the updated React Server Component payload without losing unaffected client-side React state (e.g., useState) or browser state (e.g., scroll position).\\n\\n### Method\\nGET/Refresh\\n\\n### Signature\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\nrouter.refresh(): void\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n### Parameters\\nNone\\n\\n### Usage Example\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;typescript\\n// Refresh current route and server data\\nrouter.refresh()\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\\n\\n### Behavior Notes\\n- Preserves client-side React state (useState values)\\n- Preserves browser state (scroll position)\\n- Re-fetches server data and re-renders Server Components\\n- Could reproduce the same result if fetch requests are cached\\n- Dynamic APIs like cookies and headers could change the response\\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\"}]}"
}

User decision: **accepted**

Status: **completed**

---



---


Context7 MCP integration is working. Verified by:

1. Resolving a library ID: searched for "next.js" and received multiple results
2. Retrieving documentation: fetched Next.js routing docs

## How Context7 Integration Works

The MCP server provides two main functions:

### 1. **Resolve Library ID** (`resolve-library-id`)
   - Searches for libraries/packages by name
   - Returns Context7-compatible library IDs (format: `/org/project`)
   - Example: Searching "next.js" returns `/vercel/next.js`

### 2. **Get Library Documentation** (`get-library-docs`)
   - Fetches documentation for a specific library
   - Parameters:
     - `context7CompatibleLibraryID`: The library ID (e.g., `/vercel/next.js`)
     - `mode`: `"code"` (for API references) or `"info"` (for conceptual guides)
     - `topic`: Optional topic to focus on (e.g., "routing", "hooks")
     - `page`: Page number for pagination (1-10)

## Usage in Future Conversations

I can now:
- Look up documentation for libraries you're using (Qdrant, Streamlit, etc.)
- Get up-to-date API references and code examples
- Help with integration questions using current documentation

The integration is ready to use. If you need help with a specific library or API, I can fetch the latest documentation.
